Peter, sounds like a fascinating experiment!  Like others, I'd love 
to see=
 examples of what you describe in some kind of video!  Perhaps 
you can upl=
oad it to YouTube :)  

The idea that the HyperNEAT-evolved solution looks =
more "natural" is 
very interesting, as is your chosen substrate configurat=
ion and how 
it gives the system an opportunity to utilize the body geometr=
y.

ken



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" 
<petar_chervens=
ki@...> wrote:
>
> Hello there, 
> 
> I am using the following CPPN model f=
or the substrate: 
> 
> Inputs: X1, Y1, X2, Y2, BIAS
> Outputs: Weight, Nod=
e-Bias, Node-Time_Constant
> 
> The time constant range is [0.5 .. 5.0] and=
 the weight/node-bias 
range 
> within the substrate in [-8.0 .. 8.0]. 
> T=
he weight range in the CPPN is unbounded. 
> 
> The node-specific outputs a=
re computed using (X1, Y1, BIAS) and 
the 
> others set to 0.
> 
> The acti=
vation functions used are plain sigmoid, gaussian, and 
sine. 
> The CTRNN =
substrate activates with 0.02 timestep and it is used to 
> control a 3D hu=
manoid model, simulated in a physical environment 
(using 
> Open Dynamics =
Engine http://www.ode.org ). 
> 
> The thing I notice, is the following: 
>=
 
> The first networks are simple, and so the connective patterns are. 
But=
 
> the node biases and time constants are also simple. When I watch 
an 
>=
 animaion of the activation changing in the substrate, it looks 
like it 
>=
 exibits a pattern. The simplest I've seen can be described as a 
mexican 
=
> wave travelling across the hidden nodes. 
> As the CPPNs complexify, so d=
o the activity patterns exibited. 
When 
> using regular NEAT for the probl=
em of keeping the humanoid model 
> balanced, it has moslty erratic behavio=
ur, and the lucky ones 
(with 
> high fitness) usually find a way to trick =
the system and stay in a 
> balanced position forever, without moving at al=
l. 
> But when HyperNEAT is used for this, it looks really interesting 
and=
.. 
> natural! The model is trying to balance using its arms, and it is 
> =
moving.. It looks like a drunk guy, but you note the difference. 
> I've ar=
ranged the nodes in a geometric way.. Let me explain - the 
left 
> and rig=
ht arm's outputs are separated in the left and right in the 
> substrate sp=
ace, and close to each other. So do the legs. The 
hidden 
> nodes are in t=
he center in a star/cirlular shape. I also included 
3 
> inputs (head velo=
city) in the center around 0.0, but with smaller 
> radius than the ring of=
 hidden nodes. 
> 
> Peter
>
